content.title: Crescendo Transient Ischemic Attacks
content.description: Multiple transient ischemic attacks occurring in rapid succession over hours to days, indicating highly unstable plaque and imminent stroke risk.
content.definition: Crescendo TIAs are defined as two or more TIAs within a 24-hour period or multiple TIAs with increasing frequency or severity. This pattern indicates a highly unstable carotid lesion with ongoing embolization and represents a neurologic emergency requiring urgent intervention.

definitions_and_patterns: Two or more TIAs within 24 hours
Increasing severity or duration of symptoms
risk_stratification: 7-day stroke risk: 10-20% (much higher than isolated TIA)
May progress to stroke during workup
management_principles: Urgent carotid imaging (duplex, CTA, or MRA)
CEA/CAS within 24-48 hours if significant stenosis
timing_of_intervention: Traditional 2-week delay abandoned for crescendo TIA
CAS may allow faster treatment if CEA delayed

clinical_pearls: Crescendo TIA is the most urgent indication for carotid intervention
Do not delay for 'plaque stabilization' - intervene urgently
CREST-2 and other trials support early intervention
Risk of stroke during waiting exceeds procedural risk
Some centers perform same-day CEA for crescendo TIA
